verses.text: How many are your works, O LORD! In wisdom you made them all; the earth is full of your creatures.

rsbNotes.title: Ps 104
rsbNotes.text: Ps. 104 God’s great act of creation is emphasized, reflecting the teaching and vocabulary of Gen. 1. Parallels may be observed between this song and an Egyptian hymn of Amenhotep IV (Akhenaton) to the sun. But the psalm affirms that the Creator alone, and not any aspect of creation, such as the sun, should be worshiped.

rsbNotes.title: Ps 104:24
rsbNotes.text: 104:24 In wisdom. See notes Prov. 8:22–31. The divine answer to Job (Job 38–41) contains many examples of God’s wisdom in creation. See “The Wisdom and Will of God” at Dan. 2:20.

verses.text: There is the sea, vast and spacious, teeming with creatures beyond number- living things both large and small.

rsbNotes.title: Ps 104:25
rsbNotes.text: 104:25 sea . . . creatures innumerable. The fifth day of creation (Gen. 1:20–23).

verses.text: There the ships go to and fro, and the leviathan, which you formed to frolic there.
These all look to you to give them their food at the proper time.
When you give it to them, they gather it up; when you open your hand, they are satisfied with good things.

rsbNotes.title: Ps 104:26
rsbNotes.text: 104:26 the ships . . . Leviathan. The psalmist’s imagination is caught up with God’s mysterious sea. On its surface ships glide to and fro from distant ports, while underneath lurks the monster Leviathan, here, a poetic symbol of God’s creative power (Job 41).

verses.text: When you hide your face, they are terrified; when you take away their breath, they die and return to the dust.

rsbNotes.title: Ps 104:29
rsbNotes.text: 104:29 hide your face. God is omnipresent: He is everywhere (Ps. 139). However, in His anger God withdraws covenant blessings and this is experienced as divine absence.

verses.text: When you send your Spirit, they are created, and you renew the face of the earth.
May the glory of the LORD endure forever; may the LORD rejoice in his works-

rsbNotes.title: Ps 104:30
rsbNotes.text: 104:30 your Spirit. This alludes to Gen. 2:4–8, the creation of man on the sixth day.

verses.text: he who looks at the earth, and it trembles, who touches the mountains, and they smoke.
I will sing to the LORD all my life; I will sing praise to my God as long as I live.
May my meditation be pleasing to him, as I rejoice in the LORD.

rsbNotes.title: Ps 104:32
rsbNotes.text: 104:32 the mountains . . . smoke. Hills are the symbol of stability and firmness (Ps. 46:2, 3), but God’s mere touch sets them aflame.

verses.text: But may sinners vanish from the earth and the wicked be no more. Praise the LORD, O my soul. Praise the LORD.

rsbNotes.title: Ps 104:35
rsbNotes.text: 104:35 Let sinners be consumed from the earth. The psalmist would like to see the removal of everything that opposes the godly order he has so eloquently described.
